editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What happiness waits on the life at court,
What dear content, greatness, delight and ease?
What ever-springing hopes, what tides of honour,
That raise their fortunes to the height of wishes?
What can be more in man, what more in nature,
Then to be great and feared? A courtier,
A noble courtier, 'tis a name that draws
Wonder, and duty, from all eyes and knees.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And so your worship's land within the walls,
Where you shall have it all enclosed and sure.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Peace knave; dull creature, bred of sweat and smoke,
These mysteries are far above thy faith:
But thou shalt see â€”

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And then I shall believe;
Your fair revenues, turned into fair suits,
I shall believe your tenants bruised and rent
Under the weight of coaches, all your state
Drawn through the streets in triumph, suits for places
Plied with a mine of gold, and being got
Fed with a great stream, I shall believe all this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You shall believe, and know me glorious.
Cousin good day and health. Enter Cozen.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: The same to you sir,
And more, without my wishes, could you know
What calm content dwells in a private house:
Yet look into yourself, retire: this place
Of promises, and protestations, fits
Minds only bent to ruin, you should know this,
You have their language perfect, you have tutors
I do not doubt sufficient: but beware.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are merry cousin:

sp.speaker: Cozen.
sp.l: Yet your patience,
You shall learn that too, but not like itself
Where it is held a virtue; tell me sir,
Have you cast up your state, rated your land,
And find it able to endure the change
Of time and fashion? is it always harvest?
Always vintage? have you ships at sea
To bring you gold, and stone from rich Peru
Monthly returning treasure? doth the King
Open his large exchequer to your hands
And bid you be a great man? can your wife
Coin off her beauty? or the week allow
Suits to each day? and know no ebb in honour?
If these be possible, and can hold out,
Then be a courtier still, and still be wasting,

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Cousin, pray give me leave:

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I have done.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: I could requite your gall, and in a strain
As bitter, and as full of rhubarb, preached
Against your country life, but 'tis below me
And only subject to my pity, know
The eminent court, to them that can be wise,
And fasten on her blessings, is a sun
That draws men up from course and earthly being,
I mean these men of merit that have power
And reason to make good her benefits,
Learns them a manly boldness, gives their tongues
Sweetness of language, makes them apt to please;
Files of all rudeness, and uncivil behaviour,
Shows them as neat in carriage as in clothes;
Cousin have you ever seen the court?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: No sir,
Nor am I yet in travail with that longing.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O the state, and greatness of that place
Where men are found
Only to give the first creation glory!
Those are the models of the ancient world
Left like the Roman statues to stir up
Our following hopes, the place itself puts on
The brow of majesty, and flings her lustre
Like the air newly lightened, form, and order,
Are only there themselves, unforced, and sound,
As they were first created to this place.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: You nobly came, but will go from thence base.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Twas very pretty, and a good conceit;
You have a wit good cousin, I do joy in't,
Keep it for court: but to myself again,
When I have viewed these pieces, turned these eyes,
And with some taste of superstition,
Looked on the wealth of nature, the fair dames,
Beauties, that lights the court, and makes it show
Like a fair heaven, in a frosty night:
And amongst these mine, not poorest, 'tis for tongues
Of blessed poets, such as Orpheus was,
To give their worth and praises; oh dear cousin:
You have a wife, and fair, bring her hither,
Let her not live to be the mistress of a farmer's heir
And be confined ever to a serge,
Far courser then my horse-cloth.
Let her have velvets, tiffanies, jewels, pearls,
A coach, an usher, and her two lackeys,
And I will send my wife to give her rules,
And read the rudiments of court to her.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Sir I had rather send her to Virginia
To help to propagate the English nation. Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Sirrah, how slept your mistress, and what visitants
Are to pay service?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir as I came out,
Two counts were newly entered.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This is greatness,
But few such servants wait a country beauty.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: They are the more to thank their modesty,
God keep my wife, and all my issue female
From such uprisings. Enter a doctor.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What? my learned doctor?
You will be welcome, give her health and youth
And I will give you gold. Exit doctor.
Cousin, how savours this? is it not sweet?
And very great, tastes it not of nobleness?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Faith sir my palate is too dull and lazy
I cannot taste it, 'tis not for my relish,
But be so still.
Since your own misery must first reclaim ye,
To which I leave you sir,
If you will yet be happy, leave the humour
And base subjection to your wife, be wise,
And let her know with speed you are her husband,
I shall be glad to hear it.
My horse is sent for. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Even such another country thing as this
Was I, such a piece of dirt, so heavy,
So provident to heap up ignorance,
And be an ass: such musty clothes wore I,
So old and threadbare: I do yet remember
Divers young gallants lighting at my gate,
To see my honoured wife, have offered pence,
And bid me walk their horses, such a slave
Was I in show then: but my eyes are opened.
Many sweet morrows to my worthy wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis well, and aptly given, as much for you,
But to my present business, which is money â€”

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Lady I have none left.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I hope you dare not say so, nor imagine so base and low,
A thought: I have none left.
Are these words fitting for a man of worth,
And one of your full credit? Do you know
The place you live in? me, and what I labour
For, you? and your advancement?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes my dearest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And do you pop me off with this slight answer,
In troth I have none left? in troth you must have;
Nay stare not, 'tis most true, send speedily
To all that love you, let your people fly
Like thunder through the city,
And not return under five thousand crowns.
Try all, take all, let not a wealthy merchant be untempted
Or any that hath the name of money,
Take up at any use, give band, or land,
Or mighty statutes able by their strength
To tie up Sampson were he now alive,
There must be money gotten; for be persuaded,
If we fall now, or be but seen to shrink,
Under our fair beginnings, 'tis our ruin,
And then goodnight to all, (But our disgrace)
Farewell the hope of coming happiness,
And all the aims we levied at so long.
Are ye not moved at this? no sense of want,
Towards yourself yet breeding? be old,
And common; jaded to the eyes
Of grooms, and pages, chambermaids, and garders,
And when you have done, put your poor house in order
And hang yourself, for such must be the end
Of him that willingly forsakes his hopes
And hath a joy to tumble to his ruin.
All that I say is certain, if ye fail
Do not impute me with it, I am clear.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Now heaven forbid I should do wrong to you
My dearest wife, and madam; yet give leave
To your poor creature to unfold himself.
You know my debts are many more than means,
My bands not taken in, my friends at home
Drawn dry with these expenses, my poor tenants
More full of want than we, then what new course
Can I beget to raise those crowns by? speak,
And I shall execute.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Pray tell me true,
Have you not land in the country?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pardon me, I had forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, you must remember it,
There is no remedy, this land must be
In Paris ere tomorrow night.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It shall, let me consider, some 300. acres
Will serve the turn.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Twill furnish at all points,
Now you speak like yourself, and know like him,
That means to be man, suspect no less
For the return will give ye five for one,
You shall be great tomorrow, I have said it.
Farewell, and see this business be afoot
With expedition. Exit wife.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Health, all joy, and honour
Wait on my lovely wife. What? Jaques, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir did you call?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I did so, hie the Jaques.
Down to the bank, and there to some good merchant
(Conceive me well good Jaques, and be private)
Offer 300. acres of my land:
Say it is choice, and fertile, ask upon it
Five thousand crowns, this is the business
I must employ thee in, be wise and speedy.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir do not do this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Knave I must have money.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If you have money thus, your knave must tell ye
You will not have a foot of land left, be more wary
And more friend to yourself, this honest land
Your worship has discarded, has been true,
And done you loyal service.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Gentle Jaques,
You have a merry wit, employ it well
About the business you have now in hand.
When ye come back, inquire me in the presence,
If not, in the tennis-court, or at my house. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If this vain hold, I know where to inquire ye.
Five thousand crowns, this with good husbandry
May hold a month out, than 5000. more,
And more land a bleeding for't, as many more
And more land laid aside. God and st. Dennis
Keep honest minded young men bachelors.
'Tis strange my Mr. should be yet so young
A puppy, that he cannot see his fall
And got so near the sun. I'll to his cousin
And once more tell him on't, if he fail,
Then to my mortgage, next unto my sale. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Longovile, Bewford, and the servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Gentlemen, hold on discourse a while,
I shall return with knowledge how, and where
We shall have best access unto my mistress
To tender your devotions.Exit

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Be it so:
Now to our first discourse.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I prithee peace;
Thou canst not be so bad, or make me know
Such things are living, do not give thyself
So common and so idle, so open vile,
So great a wronger of thy worth, so low,
I cannot, nor I must not credit thee.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Now by this light I am a whoremaster,
An open and an excellent whoremaster,
And take a special glory that I am so:
I thank my stars I am a whoremaster,
And such a one as dare be known and seen,
And pointed at to be a noble wencher.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Do not let all ears hear this, hark ye sir,
I am myself a whoremaster, I am
Believe it sir (In private be it spoken)
I love a whore directly, most men are wenchers,
And have professed the science, few men
That looks upon ye now, but whoremasters,
Or have a full desire to be so.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: This is noble.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: It is without all question, being private,
And held as needful as intelligence,
But being once discovered, blown abroad,
And known to common senses, 'tis no more
Than geometrical rules in carpenters
That only know some measure of an art,
But are not grounded: be no more deceived,
I have a conscience to reclaim you, sir.
Mistake me not: I do not bid you leave your whore
Or less to love her; forbid it
I should be such a villain to my friend,
Or so unnatural: 'twas never harboured here,
Learn to be secret first, then strike your deer.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your fair instructions Monsieur I shall learn.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: And you shall have them: I desire your care.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: They are your servants.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: You must not love.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I mean a lady, there's danger
She hath an usher and a waiting-gentlewoman,
A page, a coachman, these are feed, and fee'd
And yet for all that will be prating.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: You understand me sir, they will discover't,
And there is a loss of credit: table talk
Will be the end of this, or worse, than that;
Will this be worthy of a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Proceed good sir.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Next leave your city dame;
The best of that tribe are most merely coy,
Or most extremely foolish, both which vices
Are no great stirrers up, unless in husbands
That owe this cattle, fearing her that's coy
To be but seeming, her that's fool too forward.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: This is the rarest fellow, and the soundest
I mean in knowledge, that ere wore a codpiece,
Has found out that will pass all Italy,
All France and England, to their shames I speak
And to the griefs of all their gentlemen
The noble theory of luxury.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Your patience,
And I will lay before your eyes a course
That I myself found out, 'tis excellent,
Easy, and full of freedom.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O good sir,
You rack me till I know it.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: This it is,
When your desire is up, your blood well heated
And apt for sweet encounter, choose the night
And with the night your wench the streets have store,
There seize upon her, get her to your chamber,
Give her a cardecu, 'tis royal payment
When ye are dull, dismiss her, no man knows
Nor she herself, who hath encountered her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O but their faces.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Ne'er talk of faces:
The night allows her equal with a Duchess,
Imagination doth all think her fair,
And great, clapped in velvet, she is so
Sir, I have tried those, and do find it certain
It never fails me, 'tis but twelve nights since
My last experience.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O my meiching varlet, I'll fit ye as I live.
'Tis excellent, I'll be your scholar sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You are fairly welcome both: troth gentlemen
You have been strangers, I could chide you for't,
And task ye with unkindness, what's the news?
The town was never empty of some novelty;
Servant, what's your intelligence?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Faith nothing.
I have not heard of any worth relating

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Nor I sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Then give me attention,
Monsieur shattillion's mad.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Mad?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Mad as may-butter,
And which is more, mad for a wench.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis strange, and full of pity.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: All that comes near him
He thinks are come of purpose to betray him,
Being full of strange conceit: the wench he loved
Stood very near the crown.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Alas good monsieur;
A' was a proper man, and fair demeaned,
A person worthy of a better temper.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: He is strong opinioned that the wench he loved
Remains close prisoner by the King's command:
Fearing her title, when the poor grieved gentlewoman
Follows him much lamenting, and much loving
In hope to make him well, he knows her not,
Nor any else that comes to visit him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Let's walk in gentlemen, and there discourse
His further miseries, you shall stay dinner,
In truth you must obey.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We are your servants. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: There's no good to be done, no cure to be wrought
Upon my desperate kinsman: I'll to horse
And leave him to the fool's whip, misery.
I shall recover twenty miles this night,
My horse stands ready, I'll away with speed.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Sir, may I crave your name?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Yes sir you may:
My name is Cleremon.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: 'Tis well, your faction?
What party knit you with?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I know no parties,
Nor no factions sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then wear this cross of white:
And where you see the like they are my friends,
Observe them well, the time is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Sir keep your cross, I'll wear none, sure this fellow
Is much beside himself, grown mad.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: A word sir;
You can pick nothing out of this, this cross
Is nothing but a cross, a very cross,
Plain without spell or witchcraft, search it,
You may suspect, and well, there's poison in't,
Powder, or wildfire, but 'tis nothing so.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I do believe you sir, 'tis a plain cross.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then do your worst, I care not, tell the King,
Let him know all this, as I am sure he shall;
When you have spit your venom, then will I
Stand up a faithful, and a loyal subject,
And so God save his grace, this is no treason.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.p: He is march mad, farewell Monsieur. Exit Couzen.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Farewell;
I shall be here attending, 'tis my life
They aim at, there's no way to save it, well
Let 'em spread all their nets: they shall not draw me
Into any open treason, I can see,
And can beware, I have my wits about me,
I thank heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: There he goes,
That was the fairest hope the French court bred,
The worthiest and the sweetest tempered spirit,
The truest, and the valiantest, the best of judgement,
Till most unhappy I: severed those virtues
And turned his wit wild with a coy denial,
Which heaven forgive me, and be pleased, oh heaven
To give again his senses: that my love
May strike off all my follies.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I Sis

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Your will with me sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Sir I come.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: From the dread sovereign King, I know it lady,
He is a gracious prince, long may he live,
Pertain you to his chamber?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: No indeed sir,
That place is not for women, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Yes, I do know you.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: What's my name? pray you speak.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: That's all one, I do know you and your business,
You are discovered lady, I am wary,
It stands upon my life; pray excuse me,
The best man of this kingdom sent you hither,
To dive into me, have I touched you? ha?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: You are deceived sir, I come from your love,
That sends you fair commends, and many kisses.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Alas poor soul how does she? is she living?
Keeps she her bed still?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Still sir, she is living,
And well, and shall do so.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Are ye in counsel?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: No sir, nor any of my sex.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Why so,
If you had been in counsel, you would know,
Her time to be but slender; she must die.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I do believe it sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: And suddenly,
She stands too near a fortune.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: 'Tis so,
There is no jesting with a prince's title,
Would we had both been born of common parents
And lived a private and retired life,
In homely cottage, we had then enjoyed,
Our loves, and our embraces, these are things,
That cannot tend to treason â€”

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: I am wretched.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: O I pray as often for the King as any,
And with as true a heart, for's continuance,
And do moreover pray his heirs may live;
And their fair issues, then as I am bound
For all the states and commons, if these prayers
Be any ways ambitious, I submit,
And lay my head down let 'em take it off;
You may inform against me, but withal
Remember my obedience to the crown,
And service to the state.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Good sir, I love ye.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then love the gracious King, and say with me

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Heaven save his grace.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: This is strange â€”
A woman should be sent to undermine me,
And buzz love into me to try my spirit;
Offer me kisses and enticing follies,
To make me open and betray myself;
It was a subtle and a dangerous plot,
And very soundly followed, farewell lady,
Let me have equal hearing, and relate
I am an honest man. Heaven save the King. Exit.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I'll never leave him, till by art or prayer
I have restored his senses, if I make
Him perfect man again, he's mine still, when
I here abjure all loves of other men.Exit

sp.speaker: Jaques.
sp.l: Nay, good sir be persuaded, go but back,
And tell him he's undone, say nothing else;
And you shall see how things will work upon't.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Not so good Jaques, I am held an ass
A country fool, good to converse with dirt
And eat course bread, wear the worst wool,
Know nothing but the high way to Paris,
And wouldst thou have me bring these stains,
And imperfections to the rising view
Of the right worshipful thy worthy master?
They must be bright and shine, their clothes
Soft velvet and the Trojan purple
Like the Arabian gums, hung like the sun,
Their golden beams on all sides;
Such as these may come and know,
Thy master, I am base and dare not speak unto him,
He's above me.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If ever you did love him, or his state,
His name, his issue, or yourself, go back:
'Twill be an honest and a noble part
Worthy a kinsman, save 300 acres
From present execution; they have had sentence,
And cannot be reprieved, be merciful.

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: Have I not urged already all the reasons,
I had to draw him from his will? his ruin?
But all in vain, no counsel will prevail,
Has fixed himself, there's no removing Jaques,
'Twil prove but breath and labour spent in vain,
I'll to my horse, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ja..
sp.l: For god's sake sir,
As ever you have hope of joy turn back;
I'll be your slave for ever, do but go,
And I will lay such fair directions to you
That if he be not doting on his fall,
He shall recover sight, and see his danger,
And ye shall tell him of his wives abuses,
I fear, to foul against him; how she plots,
With our young monsieurs, to milk dry her husband,
And lay it on their backs, the next her pride,
Then what his debts are, and how infinite
The curses of his tenants, this will work
I'll pawn my life and head, he cries away,
I'll to my house in the country.

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: Come I'll go, and once more try him,
If he yield not, so,
The next that tries him shall be want and woe.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Jaques.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Sir.Within.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Rise Jaques 'tis grown day,
The country life is best, where quietly
Free from the clamour of the troubled court,
We may enjoy our own green shadowed walks,
And keep a moderate diet without art.
Why did I leave my house and bring my wife,
To know the manner of this subtle place?
I would when first the lust to fame an honour,
Possessed me, I had met with any evil.
But that, had I been tied to stay at home
And earn the bread for the whole family
With my own hand happy had I been.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir this is from your wonted course at home,
When did ye there keep such inordinate hours?
Go to bed late? start thrice? and call on me?
Would you were from this place; our country sleeps,
Although they were but of that moderate length
That might maintain us in our daily work.
Yet were they sound and sweet.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I Jaques, there we dreamt not of our wives, we lay together;
And needed not; now at length my cozins words,
So truly meant, mixed with thy timely prayers
So often urged, to keep me at my home,
Condemn me quite.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: 'Twas not your father's course:
He lived and died in Orleans, where he had
His vines as fruitful as experience
(Which is the art of husbandry) could make;
He had his presses for 'em, and his wines
Were held the best, and outsold other men's,
His corn and cattle served the neighbour towns
With plentiful provision, yet his thrift
Could miss one beast amongst the herd,
He ruled more where he lived, then ever you will here.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis true, why should my wife then 'gainst my good,
Persuade me to continue in this course?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why did you bring her hither at the first,
Before you warmed her blood with new delights!
Our country sports could have contented her,
When you first married her; a puppet-play
Pleased her as well as now the tilting doth.
She thought herself brave in a bugle chain,
Where orient pearl will scarce content her now.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sure Jaques, she sees something for my good
More than I do, she oft will talk to me
Of offices, and that she shortly hopes
By her acquaintance with the friends she hath
To get a place shall many times outweigh
Our great expenses, and if this be so â€”

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Think better of her words, she doth deceive you,
And only for her vain and sensual ends
Persuade ye thus. Let me be set to dwell
For ever naked in the barest soil
So you will dwell from hence.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I see my folly,
Pack up my stuff, I will away this morn.
Haste â€” haste.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Ay, now I see your father's honours
Trebling upon you, and the many prayers
The country spent for him, which almost now
Begun to turn to curses, turning back,
And falling like a timely shower
Upon ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Go, call up my wife.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But shall she not prevail,
And sway you, as she oft hath done before?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will not hear her, but rail on her
Till I be ten miles off.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: If you be forty,
'Twill not be worse sir:

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Call her up,

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I will sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why what an ass was I that such a thing
As a wife is could rule me?
Know not I that woman was created for the man,
That her desires, nay all her thoughts should be
As his are? is my sense restored at length?
Now she shall know, that which she should desire,
She hath a husband that can govern her,
If her desires leads me against my will;
Are you come?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What sad unwonted course
Makes you raise me so soon, that went to bed
So late lastnight.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O you shall go to bed sooner hereafter,
And be raised again at thrifty hours,
In summertime we'll walk
An hour after our supper, and to bed,
In winter you shall have a set at cards,
And set your maids to work.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will no more of your new tricks, your honours,
Your offices, and all your large preferments,
Which still you beat into my ears, hang o'er me.
I'll leave behind for others, the great sway
Which I shall bear at court: my living here
With countenance of your honoured friends
I'll be content to lose: for you speak this
Only that you may still continue here
In wanton ease: and draw me to consume
In clothes and other things idle for show
That which my father got with honest thrift.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why, who hath been with you sir,
That you talk thus out of frame.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You make a fool of me:
You provide one to bid me forth to supper
And make me promise; then must some one or other
Invite you forth, if you have born yourself
Loosely to any gentleman in my sight
At home, you ask me how I like the carriage,
Whether it were not rarely for my good,
And opened not a way to my preferment?
Come I perceive all: talk not, we'll away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why sir, you'll stay till the next triumph
Day be passed?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Ay, you have kept me here triumphing
This seven years, and I have ridden through the streets,
And bought embroidered hose and foot-cloths too,
To show a subject's zeal, I road before
In this most gorgeous habit, and saluted
All the acquaintance I could espy
From any window, these were ways ye told me
To raise me; I see all: make you ready straight,
And in that gown which you came first to town in,
Your safeguard, cloak, and your hood suitable:
Thus on a double gelding shall you amble,
And my man Jaques shall be set before you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But will you go?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And shall I too?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: And you shall too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But shall I by this light?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Why by this light you shall.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Then by this light
You have no care of your estate, and mine.
Have we been seven years venturing in a ship,
And now upon return with a fair wind
And a calm sea, full fraught with our own wishes
Laden with wealth and honour to the brim,
And shall we fly away and not receive it?
Have we been tilling, sowing, labouring
With pain and charge a long and tedious winter,
And when we see the corn above the ground,
Youthful as is the morn and full ear
That promises to stuff our spacious garners,
Shall we then let it rot, and never reap it?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Wife talk no more, your rhetoric comes too late,
I am inflexible; and how dear you
Adventure to direct my course of life?
Was not the husband mad to rule the wife?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis true but where the man doth miss his way,
It is the woman's part to set him right;
So fathers have a power to guide their sons
In all their courses, yet you oft have seen
Poor little children that have both their eyes
Lead their blind fathers.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: She has a plaguy wit,
I say you're but a little piece of man.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But such a piece, as being ta'en away
Man cannot last: the fairest and tallest ship,
That ever sailed, is by a little piece of the same
Wood, steered right, and turned about.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: 'Tis true she says, her answers stand with reason.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But sir, your cousin put this in your head
Who is an enemy to your preferment,
Because I should not take place of his wife;
Come by this kiss thou shalt not go sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Come, by this kiss I will go sweetheart,
On with your riding stuff; I know your tricks,
And if preferment fall ere you be ready,
'Tis welcome, else adieu the city life.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Well sir I will obey.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: About it then,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To please your humour I would dress myself,
In the most loathsome habit you could name
Or travel any whether o'er the world
If you command me, it shall ne'er be said
The frailty of a woman whose weak mind,
Is often set on loose delights and shows,
Hath drawn her husband to consume his state,
In the vain hope of that which never fell.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: About it then, women are pleasant creatures,
When once a man begins to know himself.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: But hark you sir because I will be sure,
You shall have no excuse, no word to say
In your defence hereafter; when you see
What honours were prepared for you and me
Which you thus willingly have thrown away,
I tell you I did look for present honour,
This morning for you, which I know had come
But if they do not come ere I am ready
(Which I will be the sooner lest they should)
When I am once set in a country life,
Not all the power of earth shall alter me,
Not all your prayers or threats shall make me speak
The least words to my honourable friends
To do you any grace.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will not wish it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And never more hope to be honourable,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My hopes are lower.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: As I live you shall not,
You shall be so far from the name of noble
That you shall never see a lord again;
You shall not see a mask, or barriers,
Or tilting or a solemn christening,
Or a great marriage, or new fireworks,
Or any bravery; but you shall live
At home bespotted with your own loved dirt
In scurvy clothes as you were wont to do,
And to content you I will live so too.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: 'Tis all I wish, make haste the day draws on,
It shall be my care to see your stuff pact up.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It shall be my care to gull you: you shall stay. Ex. Gen.
And more than so entreat me humbly too
You shall have honours presently; Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Bring hither, pen, ink, and paper.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: 'Tis here.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Your master will not stay,
Unless preferment come within an hour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let him command one of the city gates
In time of mutiny, or you may provide him,
To be one of the counsel for invading,
Some savage country to plant christian faith.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, no, I have it for him, call my page
Now my dear husband there it is will fit you. Exit. Maria
And when the world shall see what I have done,
Let it not move the spleen of any wife,
To make an ass of her beloved husband
Without good ground, but if they will be drawn
To any reason by you, do not gull them;
But if they grow conceited of themselves,
And be fine gentlemen, have no mercy,
Publish them to the world, 'twill do them good
When they shall see their follies understood,
Go bear these letters to my servant,
And bid him make haste, I will dress myself,
In all the journey clothes I used before
Not to ride but to make the laughter more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Is all pact up?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: All, all sir, there is no tumbler,
Runs throw his hoop with more dexterity
Than I about this business: 'tis a day
That I have long longed to see.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come where's my spurs?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Here sir, and now 'tis come.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I Jaques now
I thank my fates, I can command my wife.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am glad to see it sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I do not love always,
To be made a puppy, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But yet methinks your worship does not look,
Right like a country gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will, give me my tother hat.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: So, my jerkin.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: On with it Jaques, thou and I
Will live so finely in the country, Jaques,
And have such pleasant walks into the woods
A mornings, and then bring whom riding rods,
And walking staves â€”

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And I will bear them sir,
And scourge-sticks for the children.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: So thou shalt,
And thou shalt do all, over see my work folks
And at the week's end pay them all their wages.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I will sir, so your worship give me money.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Thou shalt receive all too: give me my drawers

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: They are ready sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And I will make thy mistress,
My wife, look to her laundry and her dairy,
That we may have our linen clean on Sundays.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And holy days.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I and ere we walk about the grounds
Provide our breakfast,
Or she shall smoke, I'll have her a good housewife
She shall not make a voyage to her sisters,
But she shall live at home,
And feed her pullen fat, and see her maids
In bed before her, and lock all the doors

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why that will be a life for Kings and Queens.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Give me my scarf with the great button quickly.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: 'Tis done sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Now my mittens.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Here they are sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: 'Tis well? now my great dagger.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Why so; thus it should be, now my riding rod.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: There's nothing wanting sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Another, man, to stick under my girdle.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: There it is.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: All is well.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why now methinks your worship looks
Like to yourself, a man of means and credit,
So did your grave and famous ancestors,
Ride up and down to fairs, and cheapen cattle.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Go, hasten your mistress, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: It shall be done. Exit Jaques.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Who's that? who's that boy?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I think it be my master.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Who, he that walks in grey whisking his riding rod?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yes sir, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed; he is prepared
For his new journey; when I wink upon you
Run out and tell the gentleman 'tis time â€”
Monsieur good day.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: Monsieur your mistress is within, but yet not ready.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My business is with you sir; 'tis reported,
I know not whether by some enemy
Maliciously that envies your great hopes,
And would be ready to sow discontents
Betwixt his majesty and you, or truly,
Which on my faith I would be sorry for,
That you intend to leave the court in haste.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Faith sir within this half hour. Jaques?

sp.speaker: Jaques within:
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Is my wife ready?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Presently.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: But sir,
I needs must tell you as I am your friend,
You should have ta'en your journey privater
For 'tis already blazed about the court.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Why sir, I hope it is no treason, is it?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis true sir, but 'tis grown the common talk,
There's no discovery else held, and in the presence
All the nobility and gentry
Have nothing in their mouths but only this,
Monsieur Marine that noble gentleman,
Is now departing hence, every man's face
Looks ghastly on his fellows, such a sadness
(Before this day) I ne'er beheld in court,
Men's hearts begin to fail them when they hear it,
In expectation of the great event
That needs must follow it, pray heaven it be good!

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Why I had rather all their hearts should fail
Then I stay here until my purse fail me.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: But yet you are a subject, and beware
I charge you by the love I bear to you
How you do venture rashly on a course
To make your sovereign jealous of your deeds
For princes' jealousies where they love most,
Are easily found, but they be hardly lost.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Come these are tricks, I smell 'em, I will go.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Have I not still professed myself your friend?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Yes, but you never showed it to me yet.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: But now I will, because I see you wise,
And give ye thus much light into a business
That came to me but now, be resolute,
Stand stiffly to it that you will depart,
And presently.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Why so I mean to do.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: And by this light you may be what you will;
Will you be secret sir?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The King does fear you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: And is now in counsel;

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: About me;

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: About you, and you be wise,
You'll find he's in counsel about you?
His counsellors have told him all the truth.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What truth?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why? that which now he knows too well.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: That you have followed him seven years
With a great train: and though he have not graced you,
Yet you have dived into the hearts of thousands,
With liberality and noble carriage;
And if you should depart home preferred
All discontented, and seditious spirits
Would flock to you and thrust you into action:
With whose help, and your tenants, who doth not know
(If you were so disposed:)
How great a part of this yet fertile peaceful realm of Fran.
You might make desolate? but when the King
Heard this â€”

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What said he?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Nothing, but shook,
As never Christian prince did shake before.
And to be short you may be what you will?
But be not ambitious sir, sit down
With moderate honours, lest you make yourself
More feared.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I know sir what I have to do
In mine own business. Enter Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Where's monsieur mount Marine.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why there he stands, will you ought with him?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Yes: good day monsieur Marine.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good day to you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: His majesty doth commend himself,
Most kindly to you sir, and hath by me,
Sent you this favour: kneel down, rise a knight.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I thank his majesty.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And he doth further request you,
Not to leave the court so soon,
For though your former merits have been slighted,
After this time there shall no office fall;
Worthy your spirit, as he doth confess
There's none so great, but you shall surely have it.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Do you hear, if you yield yet you are an ass.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I'll show my service to his majesty
In greater things than these, but for this small one
I must entreat his highness to excuse me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'll bear your knightly words unto the King,
And bring his princely answer back again. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Well said, be resolute a while, I know
There is a tide of honours coming on.
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Where is this new made knight?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Let me enfold you in my arms,
Then call you lord, the King will have it so,
Who doth entreat your lordship to remember
His message sent to you by Longavile.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: If ye be dirty, and dare not mount aloft;
You may yield now, I know what I would do.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Peace, I will fit him; tell his majesty
I am a subject, and I do confess
I serve a gracious prince, that thus hath heaped
Honours on me without desert, but yet
As for the message, business urgeth me,
I must be gone, and he must pardon me,
Were he ten thousand Kings and emperors.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I'll tell him so.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why, this was like yourself.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: As he hath wrought him, 'tis the finest fellow
That ere was Christmas lord, he carries it
So truly to the life, as though he were
One of the plot to gull himself. Exit Bewf.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why so, you sent the wisest and the shrewdest
Unto the King, I swear, my honoured friend
That ever any subject sent his liege.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nay now I know I have him on the hip,
I'll follow it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: My honourable lord,
Give me your noble hand right courteous peer,
And from henceforth be a courtly Earl;
The King so wills, and subjects must obey:
Only he doth desire you to consider
Of his request.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why faith your well my lord, yield to him.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yield? why 'twas my plot.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Nay 'twas your wife's plot.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: To get preferment by it,
And thinks he now to pop me ith' mouth
But with an earldom, I'll be one step higher.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis the finest lord, I am afraid anon
He will stand upon't to share the kingdom with him.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Where's this courtly Earl?
His majesty commends his love unto you;
And will you but now grant to his request,
He bids you be a Duke, and choose of whence.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why if you yield not now, you are undone,
What can you wish to have more, but the kingdom?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: So please his majesty, I would be Du. of Burgundy
Because I like the place.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I know the King is pleased.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Then will I stay and kiss his highness' hand.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: His majesty will be a glad man when he hears it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: But how shall we keep this from the world's ear
That some one tell him not, he is no Duke?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: We'll think of that anon.
Why gentlemen, is this a gracious habit for a Duke?
Each gentle body set a finger to
To pluck the clouds of this his riding weeds
From off the orient sun of his best clothes;
I'll pluck one boot and spur off.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I another.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I'll pluck his jerkin off.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sit down my lord;
Both his spurs off at once good Longavile
And Bewford take that scarf off, and that hat
Doth not become his largely sprouting forehead.
Now set your gracious foot to this of mine,
One pluck will do it, so, off with the other.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Lo thus your servant Longavile doth pluck
The trophy of your former gentry off,
Off with his jerkin Bewford.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Didst thou never see
A nimble footed tailor stand so in his stockings,
Whilst some friend help to pluck his jerkin off,
To dance a jig?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Here's his man Jaques come
Booted and ready still.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: My mistress stays;
Why how now sir? what do your worship mean,
To pluck your grave and thrifty habit off?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My slippers, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O thou mighty Duke
Pardon this man,
That thus hath trespassed in ignorance.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I pardon him.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: His grace's slippers, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Footman, he's a Duke:
The King hath raised him above all his land.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'll to his cousin presently, and tell him so;
Oh what a dunghill country rogue was I! Exit Jaques.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: See, see, my mistress.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Let's observe their greeting.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Unto your will as every good wife ought,
I have turned all my thoughts, and now am ready.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O wife I am not worthy to kiss the least
Of all thy toes, much less thy thumb,
Which yet I would be bold with; all thy counsel
Hath been to me angelical, but mine to thee
Hath been most dirty like my mind:
Dear Duchess I must stay.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What are you mad to make me
Dress, and undress, turn and wind me,
Because you find me pliant? said I not
The whole world should not alter me, if once
I were resolved? and now you call me Duchess:
Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Lo a knight doth kneel.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A knight?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A lord.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A fool.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I say doth kneel an Earl, a Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: In drawers.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Without shoes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sure you are lunatic.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: No honoured Duchess
If you dare but believe your servants truth,
I know he is a Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: God save his grace.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I ask your grace's pardon.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Then I rise,
And here in token that all strife shall end
Betwixt thee and me, I let my drawers fall
And to thy hands I do deliver them:
Which signifies, that in all acts and speeches,
From this time forth my wife shall wear the breeches.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: An honourable composition. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Shall I believe thee Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir you may.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Didst thou not dream?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I did not.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Nor imagine?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Neither of both: I saw him great and mighty,
I saw the monsieurs bow, and heard them cry
Good health and fortune to my lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: A Duke art sure? A Duke?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am sure a Duke,
And so sure as I know myself for Jaques.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Yet the sun may dazzle? Jaques, was it not
Some lean commander of an angry blockhouse
To keep the Flemish eel-boats from invasion,
Or some bold baron able to dispend
His fifty pounds a year, and meet the foe
Upon the Kings command in gilded canvas,
And do his deeds of worth? or was it not
Some place of gain, as clerk to the great band
Of maribones, that people call the Switzers?
Men made of beufe, and sarsenet?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Is a Duke his chamber hung with nobles like a presence?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I am something wavering in my faith;
Would you would settle me, and swear 'tis so,
Is he a Duke indeed?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I swear he is.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I am satisfied, he is my kinsman. Jaques,
And I his poor unworthy cousin.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: True sir.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I might have been a Duke too, I had means,
A wife as fair as his, and as wise as his;
And could have brooked the court as well as his,
And laid about her for her husband's honour:
Oh Jaques had I ever dreamt of this,
I had prevented him.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Faith sir it came
Above our expectation, we were wise
Only in seeking to undo this honour,
Which showed our dunghill breeding and our dirt.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: But tell me Jaques,
Why could we not perceive? what dull devil
Wrought us to cross this noble course, persuading
'Twould be his overthrow? for me a courtier
Is he that knows all, Jaques, and does all,
'Tis as his noble grace hath often said,
And very wisely, Jaques, we are fools,
And understand just nothing.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Ay, as we were, I confess it.
But rising with our great master,
We shall be called to knowledge with our places,
'Tis nothing to be wise, not thus much there,
There's not the least of the billet dealers,
Nor any of the pastry, or the kitchen,
But have it in measure delicate.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Methinks this greatness of the Dukes my cousins
(I ask you mercy, Jaques, that near name
Is too familiar for me) should give promise
Of some great benefits to his attendants.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I have a suit myself, and it is sure,
Or I mistake my ends much.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: What is 't Jaques,
May I not crave the place?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes sir you shall,
'Tis to be but his grace's secretary,
Which is my little all, and my ambition,
Till my known worth shall take me by the hand
And set me higher; how the fates may do
In this poor thread of life is yet uncertain;
I was not born I take it for a trencher,
Nor to espouse my mistress dairy-maid.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I am resolved my wife shall up to court;
I'll furnish her, that is a speeding course,
And cannot choose but breed a mighty fortune;
What a fine youth was I, to let him start,
And get the rise before me? I'll dispatch
And put myself in moneys.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Mass 'tis true,
And now you talk of money, sir my business
For taking those crowns must be dispatched?
This little plot in the country lies most fit
To do his grace such serviceable uses,
I must about it.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Yet before you go
Give me your hand, and bear my humble service
To the great Duke your master, and his Duchess,
And live yourself in favour: say my wife
Shall there attend them shortly, so farewell.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'll see you mounted sir.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: It may not be,
Your place is far above it, spare yourself,
And know I am your servant, fare ye well. Exit cousin.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir I shall rest to be commanded by you;
This place of secretary will not content me,
I must be more and greater, let me see,
To be a baron is no such great matter
As people take it: for say I were a count,
I am still an under person to this Duke,
Which methinks sounds but harshly: but a Duke?
O I am strangely taken, 'tis a Duke
Or nothing, I'll advise upon't, and see
What may be done by wit and industry. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It must be carried closely with a care
That no man speak unto him, or come near him
Without our private knowledge, or be made
Aforehand to our practice:
My good husband
I shall entreat you now to stay a while,
And prove a noble coxcomb:
Gentlemen,
Your counsel and advice about this carriage.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Alas good man, I do begin to mourn
His dire massacre: what a persecution
Is pouring down upon him? sure he is sinful.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Let him be kept in is chamber under show
Of state and dignity, and no man suffered
To see his noble face, or have access,
But we that are conspirators.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Or else down with him into the country amongst his tenants,
There he may live far longer in his greatness,
And play the fool in pomp amongst his fellows.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, he shall play the fool in the city, and stay
I will not lose the greatness of this jest
That shall be given to my wit for the whole revenues.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Then thus we'll have a guard about his person,
That no man come too near him, and ourselves
Always in company; have him into the city
To see his face swell; whilst in divers corners,
Some of our own appointing shall be ready
To cry heaven bless your grace, long live your grace.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Servant, your counsels excellent good,
And shall be followed, 'twill be rarely strange
To see him stated thus, as though he went
A shroving through the city, or intended
To set up some new stake:
I shall not hold
From open laughter when I hear him cry
Come hither my sweet Duchess: let me kiss
Thy gracious lips: for this will be his phrases?
I fear me nothing but his legs will break
Under his mighty weight of such a greatness.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Now methinks dearest lady you are too cruel;
His very heart will freeze in knowing this.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, no, the man was never of such deepness
To make conceit his master: sir I'll assure ye
He will outlive twenty such pageants.
Were he but my cousin or my brother,
And such a desperate killer of his fortune,
In this belief he should die, though it cost me
A thousand crowns a day to hold it up;
Or were I not known his wife, and so to have
An equal feeling of this ill he suffers,
He should be thus till all the boys i'th town
Made suit to wear his badges in their hats,
And walk before his grace with sticks and nosegays,
We married women hold â€”

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis well, no more.
The Duke is entering, set your faces right,
And bow like country prologues: here he comes.
Make room afore, the Duke is entering.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: The chiefest fortunes wait upon our Duke,

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: And give him all content and happiness.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Let his great name live to the end of time.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We thank you, and are pleased to give you notice
We shall at fitter times wait on your loves,
Till when, be near us.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: 'Tis a valiant purge, and works extremely;
'Thas delivered him
Of all right worshipful and gentle humours,
And left his belly full of nobleness.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It pleased the King my master
For sundry virtues not unknown to him,
And the all-seeing state, to lend his hand
And raise me to this emminence, how this
May seem to other men, or stir the minds
Of such as are my fellow peers, I know not,
I would desire their loves in just designs.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Now by my faith he does well, very well:
Beshrew my heart I have not seen a better
Of a raw fellow, that before this day
Never rehearsed his state: 'tis marvellous well.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Is he not Duke indeed, see how he looks
As if his spirit were a last, or two
Above his veins, and stretched his noble hide.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: He's high braced like a drum, pray God he break not.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why let him break, there's but a calves-skin lost.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: May it please your grace to see the city,
'Twill be to the minds and much contentment
Of the doubtful people.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I am determined so, till my return
I leave my honoured Duchess to her chamber.
Be careful of your health, I pray you be so.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Your grace shall suffer us your humble servants
To give attendance fit so great a person
Upon your body.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am pleased so.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Away good Bewford, raise a guard sufficient
To keep him from the reach of tongues, be quick;
And do you hear, remember how the streets
Must be disposed with for cries, and salutations.
Your grace determines not to see the King â€”

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Not yet, I shall be ready ten days hence
To kiss his highness' hand, and give him thanks,
As it is fit I should for his great bounty
Set forward gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Room for the Duke there. Exeunt Duke and train.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis fit he should have room to show his mightiness,
He swells so with his poison,
'Tis better to reclaim ye thus, then make
A sheepshead of you, it had been but your due;
But I have mercy sir, and mean to reclaim you
By a directer course.
That woman is not worthy of a soul
That has the sovereign power to rule her husband,
And gives her title up, so long provided
As there be fair play, and his state not wronged.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I would be glad to know whence this new Duke springs,
The people buzz abroad, or by what title
He received his dignity, 'tis very strange
There should be such close juggling in the state,
But I am tied to silence, yet a day
May come, and soon to perfect all these doubts.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It is the mad Shattillion by my soul
I suffer much for this poor gentleman;
I'll speak to him, may be he yet knows me.
Monsieur Shattillion.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Can you give me reason from whence
This great Duke sprang that walks abroad?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Even from the King himself.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: As you are a woman, I think you may be covered
Yet your prayer would do no harm good woman.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: God preserve him.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I say amen, and so say all good subjects.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Lady as ever you have loved, or shall,
As you have hope of heaven lend your hand,
And wit to draw this poor distracted man
Under your roof from the broad eyes of people,
And wonder of the streets.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: With all my heart;
My feeling of his grief and loss is much.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Sir now you are come so near the prison, will ye
Go in, and visit your fair love: poor soul
She would be glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: This same Duke is but
Apocryphal, there's no creation
That can stand where titles are not right.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: 'Tis true sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: This is another draught upon my life;
Let me examine well the words I spoke.
The words I spoke were, that this novel Duke
Is not o'th' true making, 'tis to me most certain.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You are as right sir as you went by line.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: And to the grief of many thousands more.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: If there be any such, God comfort them.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Whose mouths may open when the time shall please;
I'm betrayed, commend me to the King,
And tell him I am sound, and crave but justice;
You shall not need to have your guard upon me,
Which I am sure are placed for my attachment;
Lead on; I'm obedient to my bonds.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Good sir be not displeased with us;
We are but servants to his highness' will,
To make that good.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I do forgive you even with my heart;
Shall I entreat a favour?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: To see my love before that fatal stroke,
And publish to the world my christian death,
And true obedience to the crown of France.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I hope it shall not need sir, for there is mercy
As well as justice in his royal heart. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.l: Every man take his corner, here am I,
You there, and you in that place, so be perfect,
Have a great care your cries be loud; and faces
Full of dejected fear and humbleness.
He comes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Fie how these streets are charged and swolled
With these same rascally people? give more room,
Or I shall have occasion to distribute
A martial alms amongst you; as I am a gentleman
I have not seen such rude disorder,
They follow him like a prize, there's no true gaper
Like to your citizen, he will be sure
The bears shall not pass by his door in peace,
But he and all his family will follow.
Room there afore? Sound?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Give room, and keep your places
And you may see enough; keep your places.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: These people are too far unmannered, thus
To stop your grace's way with multitudes.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Rebuke them not good Monsieur 'tis their loves
Which I will answer, if it please my stars
To spare me life and health.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.l: Bless your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.l: Now heaven preserve your happy days:

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I thank you too.

sp.speaker: 3 gentleman
sp.l: Now heaven save your grace;

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I thank you all.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: On there before.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Stand gentlemen, stay yet a while,
For I am minded to impart my love
To these good people, and my friends
Whose love and prayers for my greatness,
Are equal in abundance, note me well,
And with my words; my heart? for as the tree â€”

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Your grace had best beware, 'twil be informed
Your greatness with the people.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I had more
My honest and ingenious people. â€” but
The weight of business hath prevented me.
I am called from you: but this tree I spoke of
Shall bring forth fruit I hope to your content,
And so I share my bowels amongst you all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: A noble Duke, a very noble Duke.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Afore there gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: You're faithfully met good monsieur mount Marine.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Be advised, the time is altered.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Is he not the same man he was afore?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Still the same man to you sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You have received mighty grace, be thankful.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Let me not die in ignorance;

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You shall not.
Then know the King out of his love hath pleased
To style him Duke of Burgundy.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: O great Duke,
Thus low, I plead for pardon, and desire
To be enrolled amongst your poorest slaves.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sir you have mercy, and withal my hand,
From henceforth let me call you one of mine.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Make room afore there, and dismiss the people.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Every man to his house in peace and quiet.

sp.speaker: People
sp.l: Now heaven preserve the Duke, heaven bless the Duke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This letter came this morn from my cousin
To the great lady, high and mighty Duchess
Of Burgundy, be these delivered oh,
For a stronger lace to keep my breath
That I may laugh the nine days till the wonder
Fall to an ebb: the high and mighty Duchess?
The high and mighty God? what a style is this?
Methinks it goes like a duchy lope-man,
A ladder of 100. rounds will fail
To reach the top on't, well my gentle cousin
I know by these contents your itch of honour;
You must to the court, you say, and very shortly:
You shall be welcome; and if your wife have wit
I'll put her in a thriving course, if not
Her own sin on her own head, not a blot
Shall stain my reputation, only this
I must for health's sake sometimes
Make an ass of the tame moil my husband;
'Twill do him good, and give him fresher brains,
Me fresher blood.
Now for the noble Duke, I hear him coming.
Your grace is well returned.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: As well as may be:
Never in younger health, never more able:
I mean to be your bedfellow this night,
Let me have good encounter.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.l: Bless me heaven
What a hot meat this greatness is?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: It may be so,
For I'll be sworn he hath not got a snap
This two months on my knowledge, or her woman
Is dammed for swearing it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I thank you gentlemen for your attendance
And also your great pains, pray know my lodgings
Better and oftener, do so gentlemen.
Now by my honour, as I am a prince,
I speak sincerely, know my lodgings better,
And be not strangers, I shall see your service
And your deservings, when you least expect.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We humbly thank your grace for this great favour.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Jaques?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be ready for the country,
And let my tenants know the Kings great love:
Say I would see them, but the weight at court
Lies heavy on my shoulders: let them know
I do expect their duties in attendance
Against the next feast, wait for my coming
To take up post-horse , and be full of speed. Exit Jaques.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I would desire your grace â€”

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You shall desire, and have your
Full desire, sweet Duchess speak.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To have some conference with a gentleman
That seems not altogether void of reason?
He talks of titles, and things near the crown,
And knowing none so fit as your good grace,
To give the difference in such points of state â€”

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What is he? If he be noble, or have any part
That's worthy our converse, we do accept him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I can assure your grace his strain is noble,
But he's very subtle.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let him be so.
Let him have all the brains, I shall demonstrate
How this most Christian crown of France can bear
No other show of title than the Kings.
I will go in and meditate for half an hour,
And then be ready for him presently,
I will convert him quickly or confound him.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Is mad Shattillion here?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Is here, and's lady,
I prithee servant fetch him hither.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why, what do you mean to put him to?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: To chat with the mad lad my husband;
'Twill be brave to hear them speak, babble,
Stare, and prate.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: But what shall be the end of all this, lady?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Leave that to me, now for the grand dispute,
For see here comes Shattillion: as I live methinks
All France should bear part of his griefs.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I le fetch my lord the Duke.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Where am I now, or whether will you lead me?
To my death? I crave my privilege,
I must not die but by just course of law.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: His majesty hath sent by me your pardon,
He meant not you should die; but would entreat you
To lay the full state of your title open,
Unto a grave and noble gentleman.
The Duke of Burgundy who here doth come,
Who either by his wisdom will confute you,
Or else inform and satisfy the King.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: May 't please your grace, this is the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this he that chops logic with my liege?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: D'ye mock me? you are great, the time will come
When you shall be as much contemned as I,
Where are the ancient compliments of France,
That upstarts brave the princes of the blood?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your title sir, in short.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: He must sir,
Be a better states man then yourself, that can
Trip me in any thing, I will not speak
Before these witnesses.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Depart the room, for none shall stay,
No not my dearest Duchess.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: We'll stand behind the arras and hear all. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In that chair take your place, I in this,
Discourse your title now.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Sir you shall know,
My loves true title, mine by marriage,
Setting aside the first race of French Kings
Which will not here concern us, as Pharamont,
With Clodian, Meron, and Chilperik,
And to come down unto the second race,
Which we will likewise slip â€”

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But take me with you.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I pray you give me leave, of Martell Charles,
The father of King pippin, who was, sir,
To Charles the great and famous Charlemagne.
And to come to the third race of French Kings,
Which will not be great pertinent in this cause,
Betwixt the King and me, of which you know
Hugh Capet was the first,
Next his son Robert, Henry then, and Philip
With Lewis, and his son a Lewis too,
And of that name the seventy, but all this
Springs from a female as it shall appear.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now give me leave, I grant you this your title
At the first sight carries some show of truth;
But if ye weigh it well ye shall find light.
Is not his majesty possessed in peace,
And justice executed in his name,
And can you think the most Christian King
Would do this if he saw not reason for it?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: But had not the tenth Lewis a sole daughter?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: But answer me directly.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It is a most seditious question.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Is this your justice?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I stand for my King.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Was ever heir apparent thus abused?
I'll have your head for this.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why, do your worst.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Will no one stir to apprehend this traitor?
A guard about my person will? none come?
Must my own royal hands perform the deed?
Then thus I do arrest you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Treason, help.

div.stage: Enter wife, Long, and Bew. and servant.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Help, help, my lord and husband.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Help thy Duke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Forbear his grace's person.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Forbear you to touch him that,
Your heir apparent weds,
But by this hand I will have all your heads. Exit.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: How doth your grace?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why? well.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: How do you find his title?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis a dangerous one,
As can come by a female.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I 't is true,
But the law Salic, cuts him off from all.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace how stands his title?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Pew, nothing, the law shallicke cuts him off from all

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My gracious husband you must now prepare,
In all your grace's pomp to entertain
Your cousin, who is now a convertite,
And follows here, this night he will be here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be ready all in haste, I do intend,
To show before my cozens wondering faceExeunt omnes.
The greatness of my pomp, and of my place.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: Sirrah is all things carried to the tailor,
The measure and the fashion of the gown
With the best trim?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Yes sir and 'twill be ready within this two days.

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: For myself I care not,
I have a suit or two of ancient velvet;
Which with some small correcting and addition
May steal into the presence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Would my gown were ready husband, I'll lay my life,
To make you something ere tomorrow night.

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: It must not be
Before we see the Duke, and have advice,
How to behave ourselves: let's in the while,
And keep ourselves from knowledge till time shall call us

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I much admire the fierce masculine spirit,
Of this dread Amazon.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: This following night I'll have a wench in solace.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sir, I hear you,
And will be with you if I live, no more.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My lady would entreat your presence gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: We will obey your lady, she is worthy.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: You light alone, a word, or two.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your will sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Hark in your ear, wilt thou be married? speak, wilt thou marry?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Married? to whom sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: To a proper fellow, landed, and able bodied,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why do you flout me sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I swear I do not, I love thee for thy lady's sake, be free,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If I could meet such matches as you speak of,
I were a very child to lose my time, sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What sayest thou to monsieur Bewford.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir I say he's a proper gentleman, and far
Above my means to look at.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Dost thou like him?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yes sir, and ever did.

sp.speaker: Long
sp.l: He is thine own.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are too great in promises.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Be ruled and follow my advice, he shall be thine

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would you would make it good sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Do but thus,
Get thee a cushion underneath thy clothes,
And leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll be your scholar,
I cannot lose much by the venture sure.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Thou wilt lose a pretty maiden head, my rogue,
Or I am much o'th bow hand, you'll remember
If all this take effect, who did it for you,
And what I may deserve for such a kindness.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yours sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Save ye sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Save the King.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I pray you sir, which is the nearest way?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Save the King, this is the nearest way.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Which is the nearest way to the post house?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: God save the King and his post-horse .

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I pray sir direct me to the house;

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Heaven save the King, you cannot catch me sir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I do not understand you sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: You do not, I say you cannot catch me sir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Not catch you sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: No sir, nor can the King,
With all his stratagems, and his forced tricks,
Although he put his nobles in disguise;
Never so oft to sift into my words,
By course of law, lay hold upon my life.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: It is business that my lord the Duke
Is by the King employed in, and he thinks
I am acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I shall not need to rip the cause up,
From the first to you,
But if his majesty had suffered me
To marry her, though she be after him,
The right heir general to the crown of France.
I would not have conveyed her into Spain,
As it was thought, nor would I ere have joined,
With the reformed churches to make them,
Stand for my cause.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I do not think you would.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I thank you sir,
And since I see you are a favourer
Of virtues, kept in bondage;
Tell directly to my sovereign King,
For so I will acknowledge him for ever,
How you have found my stayed affections
Settled for peace, and for the present state.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And good sir tell him further this,
That notwithstanding all suggestions
Brought to him against me and all his suspicions,
Which are innumerall to my treasons,
If he will warrant me but public trial,
I'll freely yield myself into his hands;
Can he have more than this?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No by my troth.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I would his majesty would hear but reason,
As well as you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But sir you do mistake me,
For I never saw the King
In all my life but once, therefore good sir,
May it please you to show me which is the post house.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I cry you mercy sir, then you're my friend.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And such men are very rare with me,
The post house is hard by, farewell;

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I thank you sir, I must ride hard tonight ,
And it is dark already.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I am cruel to send this man directly to his death
That is my friend, and I might easily save him,
He shall not die, come back my friend, come back.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Do you not know?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And do you gather nothing by my face?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Virtue is ever innocent,
La not the fault on me, I grieve for you,
And wish that all my tears might win your safety.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Alas good friend you are undone,
The more ill fortune, mine to be the means
Of your sad overthrow: you know not me.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No truly sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Would you had never seen me,
I am a man pursued by the whole state
And sure some one hath seen me talk with you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes divers sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Why then your head is gone.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I'll out of town.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Would it were soon enough,
Stay if you love your life, or else you are taken.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I'll venture deeply for him,
Rather than to cast away an innocent,
Take courage friend, I will preserve thy life,
With hazard of mine own.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: This night thou shalt be lodged within my doors,
Which shall be all looked fast, and in the morn
I'll so provide, you shall have free access,
To the sea side and so be shipped away,
Ere any know it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Good sir suddenly I am afraid to die.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Then follow me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: This way he went, and there's the house I hope,
His better angel hath directed him,
To leave the wand'ring streets, poor gentleman.
Would I were able with as free a heart,
