To set his soul right, as I am to grieve,
The ruin of his fame, which God forgive me;
Sir if you be within, I pray sir speak to me.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I am within and will be, what are you?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A friend.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: No sir you must pardon me,
I am acquainted with none such: be speedy,
Friend there is no other remedy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A word sir I say I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: You cannot scape by any other means,
Be not fearful, God save the King,
What's your business sir?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: To speak with you.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Speak out then?

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Shall I not come up?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Thou shalt not: fly if thou beest thin own friend,
There lies the suit and all the furniture
Belonging to the head, on with it friend.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Sir do you hear?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I do, God bless the King,
It was a habit I had laid aside,
For my own person if the state had forced me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Good sir unlock your door.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Be full of speed, I see some 20 musketeers in ambush,
Whate'er thou art, know I am here and will be,
Seest thou this bloody sword that cries revenge?
Shake not my friend, through millions of these foes
I'll be thy guard and set thee safe aboard.

sp.speaker: Lou.
sp.l: Dare you not trust me sir?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: My good before me,
And my allegiance to the King I tell thee
Captain (For so I guess thee by thy arms)
And the loose flanks of halberdeers about thee,
Thou art too weak and foolish to attempt me.
If you be ready follow me, and hark you
Upon your life speak to no living wight,
Except myself.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Monsieur Shattillion?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Thou shalt not call again; thus with my sword,
And the strong faith I bear unto the King;
Whom God preserve, I will descend my chamber,
And cut thy throat, I swear I'll cut thy throat,
Steal after me and live.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I will not stay.
The fury of a man so far distracted. Exit love.
Where's the officer that dares not enter,
To entrap the life of my distressed friend?
Ay, have you hid yourself? you must be found,
What do you fear? is not authority on your side
Nay, I know the King's command
Will be your warrant, why then fear you? speak
What strange designs are these? Shattillion,
Be resolute and bear thyself upright,
Though the whole world despise thee: soft, methinks .
I heard a rushing which was like the shake
Of a discovered officer, I'll search
The whole street over, but I'll find thee out. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Jaques. in women's a parrell.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: How my joints do shake, where had I been
But for this worthy gentleman, that
Hath some touch of my infortunes: would I were
Safe under hatches once for calicut,
Farewell the pomp of court, I never more
Can hope to be a Duke or any thing,
I never more shall see thy glorious face;
Of my fair spreading lord that loved me well.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Fly you so fast? I had a sight of you,
But would not follow you; I was too wise,
You shall not lead me with a cunning trick,
Where you may catch me; poor Shatillion;
Hath the King's anger left thee never a friend?
No, all men's loves move by the breath of Kings.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: It is the gent. that saved my life, sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Bless Shatillion, another plot.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No sir, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Why, who are you?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your friend whom you preserved.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Whom I preserved?
My friend? I have no woman friend but one,
Who is to close in prison to be here;
Come near let me look on you.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: You should not be a woman by your stature.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am none sir.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I know it, then keep off,
Strange men and times! how I am still preserved?
Here they have sent a yeoman of the guard
Disguised in woman's clothes to work on me,
To make love to me; and to trap my words,
And so ensnare my life, I know you sir,
Stand back upon your peril, can this be
In christian common weals? from this time forth
I'll cut off all the means to work on me.
I'll ne'er stir from my house: and keep my doors
Locked day and night, and cheapen meat and drink
At the next shops by signs, out of my window,
And having bought it draw it up in my garters.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir, will you help me?

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Do not follow me,
I'll take a course to live despite of men. Exit Shat.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: He dares not venture for me, wretched Jaques
Thou art undone for ever and for ever,
Never to rise again: what shall I do?
Where shall I hide me? here's one to take me,
I must stand close, and not speak for my life.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: This is the time of night, and this the haunt,
In which I use to catch my wasccoatieres,
It is not very dark, no I shall spy 'em,
I have walked out in such a pitchy night.
I could not see my fingers this far off,
And yet have brought whom venison by the smell,
I hope they have not left their old walk, ah?
Have I spied you sitting by this light?
To me there's no such fine sight in the world,
As a white-apron twixt twelve and one;
See how it glisters? do you think to scape?
So now I have you fast; come and do not strive,
It takes away the edge of appetite;
Come I'll be liberal every way,Exeunt
Take heed you make no noise for waking of the watch.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Now the blessing of some happy guide,
To bring us to the Duke and we are ready.
Come forward see the door is opened,
And two of his gent. I'll speak to them,
And mark how I behave myself, God save ye;
For less I cannot wish to men of sort, and of your seeming
Are you of the Dukes?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: We are sir, and your servants, your salutes,
We give you back again with many thanks.

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: When did you hear such words before wife? peace,
Do you not dare to answer yet; is't fit
So mean a gentleman as myself should crave,
The presence of the great Duke your master?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir you may.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Shall we desire your name and business sir,
And we will presently inform him of you.

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: My name is Cleremont

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You are his grace's kinsman,
Or I am much mistaken;

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: You are right,
Some of his noble blood runs through these veins,
Though far unworthy of his grace's knowledge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sir we must all be yours; his grace's kinsman,
And we so much forgetful? 'twas a rudeness,
And must attend your pardon, thus I crave it:
First to this beauteous lady, whom I take
To be your wife sir, next your mercy.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: You have it sir, I do not like this kissing,
It lies so open to a world of wishes.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: This is the merry fellow, this is he
That must be noble too.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: And so he shall.
If all the art I have can make him noble,
I'll dub him with a knighthood; if his wife
Will be but forward, and join issue,
I like her above excellent.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Wilt please you
To walk a turn or two, whilst to the Duke
We make your coming known? Exit Ser. and Long.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I shall attend, sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: These gentlemen are very proper men,
And kiss the best that ere I tasted.
For goodness-sake husband let us never more
Come near the country, whatsoe'er betide us;
I am in malice with the memory
Of that same stinking dunghill.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Why now you are my chicken and my dear,
Love where I love, hate where I hate, now
You shall have twenty gowns, and twenty chains,
See, the door is opening.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Room afore there, the Duke is entering.

div.stage: Enter Duke, wife, Long. Servant, Maria.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: 'Tis the Duke, even he himself, be merry,
This is the golden age the poet speaks on.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I pray it be not brazened, by their faces,
And yet methinks they are the neatest pieces
For shape and cutting that ere I beheld.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Most gracious Duke, my poor spouse and myself
Do kiss your mighty foot, and next to that
The great hand of your Duchess, ever wishing
Your honours ever-springing, and your years.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Cousin?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Your grace's vassal, far unworthy
The nearness of your blood.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Correct me not, I know the word I speak,
And know the person.
Though I be something higher than the place
Where common men have motion, and descending
Down with my eye, their forms are lessened to me,
Yet from this pitch can I behold my own,
From millions of those men that have no mark,
And in my fearful stoop, can make them stand.
When others feel my soul and perish, cousin
Be comforted, you are very welcome, so
Is your fair wife: the charge of whom I give
To my own dearest and best beloved.
Tell me, have you resolved yourself for court,
And utterly renounce the slavish country,
With all the cares thereof?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I have sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Have you dismissed your eating household,
Sold your hangings of Nebuchadnezar, for such they were,
As I remember, with the furnitures
Belonging to your beds and chambers?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Have you most carefully ta'en off the lead,
From your roof weak with age, and so prevented
The ruin of your house, and clapped him
In a summer suit of thatch to keep him cool?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: All this I have performed.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then lend me all your hands, I will embrace my cousin
Who is an understanding gentleman,
And with a zeal mighty as is my name,
Once more I bid you welcome to the court;
My state again.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: As I was telling you your husband
Must be no more commander, look to that,
Be several at meat, and lodging, let him have
Board-wages and diet 'mongst his men it'h town
For pleasure if he be given to't let him have it,
Else as your own fancy shall direct you.
Cousin, you see this mighty man here: he was an ass
When he came first to town: indeed he was
Just such another coxcomb as your husband,
God bless the mark and every good man's child!
This must not stir you cousin.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Heaven forbid?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sweet Maria, provide the cushion ready for it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Receive all your advices from ourself,
Be once a day with us, and so farewell
For this time, my fair cousin; gentlemen
Conduct him to his lodging.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Farewell, and think upon my words.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I shall observe them. Exit Duke and Duchess.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Health, and the Kings continual love attend you.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: O for a private place to ease my lungs!
Heaven give me patience, such a pair of jades
Were never better ridden to this hour,
Pray heaven they hold out to the journey's end.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Twitch him aside good monsieur, whilst I break
Upon the body of his strength, his wife,
I have a constant promise: she is my own.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Ply her to windward monsieur, you have taken
The most compendious way to raise yourself,
That could have been delivered by a council.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I have some certain aims sir: but my wife â€”

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Your wife? you must not let that trouble you.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: It will sir, to see her in a stranger's arms.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: What mean you? let her alone, be wise, stir not a foot
For if you do, all your hopes are buried:
I swear you are a lost man if you stir.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I thank you sir, I will be more advised.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: But what great office do you level at?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Sir, they are kissing.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Let them kiss,
And much may do their good hearts; they must kiss
And kiss, and double kiss, and kiss again,
Or you may kiss the post for any rising:
Had your noble kinsman ever mounted
To these high spheres of honour, now he moves in,
But for the kisses of his wife?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Then I do; credit me, he had been lost,
A fellow of no mark, and no repute,
Had not his wife kissed soon, and very sweetly
She was an excellent woman, and dispatched him
To his full, being in a moment sir â€”Exit Long. And wife.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: But yet methinks he should not take her sir
Into a private room.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Now stand and flourish,
You are a made man for ever.
I do envy you if you stand your fortunes up,
You are the happiest man: but your great cousin
This day in court: well I will marry surely,
And not let every man outrun me thus.
'Tis time to be mine own friend, I live
In town here, and direct the readiest way,
To other men, and be a slave myself.

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: Nay good sir be not moved, I am your servant,
And will not be ungrateful for this knowledge.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Will you be walking home?

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: I would desire to have my wife a long.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You are too raw,
Be gone and take no notice where you left her,
Let her return at leisure, if she stay
A month 'twill be the better, understand me
This gentleman can do't. Exit Cozen.

sp.speaker: Country-gentleman
sp.l: I will sir, and wife remember me a Duke, a Duke wife.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Aboard her Longaveile she's thine own,
To me the fooling of this fool, is venery. Exit servant.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Come, prithee come, have I not crowns? behold
And follow me, here; not a word, go in
Grope by the walls, and you shall find a bed,
Lie down there, see, see, a turn or two to give
My blood some heat; and I am presently
For action, darkness by thy leave I come. Exit Bew.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am perfect in my lesson, be my speed,
Thou god of marriage, this is the door, I'll knock.

sp.speaker: Bew. within.
sp.l: Who's there? I cannot come yet.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Monsieur Bewford?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Stay till I light a candle, who are ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir? A poor gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: O come in, I'll find a time for you too, be not loud.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir you have found that time already, shame
On my soul therefore.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do you not see sir, is your light so dim?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Do you not wait on the lady mount marine?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do sir, but my love on you.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Poor soul! how cam'st thou by this big belly?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By yourself.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: By heaven I never touched your body.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, unswear that oath again, I'll tell you all;
These two years I have loved you, but the means
How to enjoy you, I did never know
Till twelve night last, when hearing of your game
To take up wenches private in the night,
I apprehended straight this course to make
Myself as one of them, and wait your coming;
I did so, and enjoyed you, and now this child
That now is quick within me: hide my shame,
And marry me: or else I must be forced â€”

sp.speaker: Long within.
sp.l: Monsieur Bewford, monsieur Bewford.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Who's that calls?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Are you a-bed ?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: No sir, the hangings.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Nay monsieur, I'll forbid that, we'll have fair play
Lend me your candle, are you taken Bewford?
A lecher of your practice, and close carriage
To be discovered thus? I am a shamed
So great a master in his art should fail,
And stagger in his grounds.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Your wide,
This woman and myself are man and wife,
And have been so this half year,
Where are you now? have I been discovered?
You cannot break so easily on me sir,
I am too wary to be opened by you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: But these are but illusions to give colour
To your most mystic lechery, but sir
The belly hath betrayed you all, it must out.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Good Longavile believe me on my faith,
I am her husband.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: On my faith I cannot unless I saw
Your hands fast and your hearts.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why Longavile when did I give that to your ears
That was not truth? by all the world she's mine,
She is my wife and to confirm you better
I give myself again, here take my hand
And I yours, we are once more married,
Will this content you?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Yes, I am believing, and God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: My loving wife I will not wrong thee,
Since I am thine and only loved of thee
From this hour I, vow myself a new man,
Be not jealous: for though I had a purpose,
To have spent an hour or two in solace otherwise,
And was provided for it, yet my love
Shall put a better temper to my blood,
Come out thou woman of unwholesome life,
Be sorry for thy sins, and learn to mend,
Nay never hide your face, you shall be seen.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Jaques, why Jaques, art thou that Jaques,
The very staff, and right hand of our Duke?
Speak, thou bearded Venus.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am he, by miracle preserved to be that Jaques,
Within this two hours gentlemen, poor Jaques
Was but as corse in grave: a man of wisdom,
That of my conscience if he had his right
Should have a pretty state, but that's all one
That noble gentleman did save this life,
I keep it for him, 'tis his own.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O Bacchus! is all the world drunk? come we'll to the Duke
And give thanks for this delivery.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not gone unto my tenants to relate
My grace and honour; and the mightiness
Of my new name which would have struck a terror
Through their course doublets, to their very hearts?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Alas great lord and master, I could scarce
With safety of my life return again
Unto your grace's house, and but for one
That had some mercy, I had sure been hanged.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My house?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes sir, this house, your house ith' town.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques we are displeased, hath it no name?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What name?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dull rogue; what hath the King bestowed
So many honours, opened all his springs,
And showered his graces down upon my head,
And has my house no name? no title yet?
Burgundy house you ass.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Your grace's mercy,
And when I was come off, and had recovered
Burgundy house, I durst not yet be seen,
But lay all night for fear of pursuivants
In Burgundy privy house.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O sir, 'tis well,
Can you remember now? but Jaques know
Since thy intended journey is so crossed,
I will go down myself this morning.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Have I not said this morning?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: But consider,
That nothing is prepared yet for your journey,
Your grace's teams not here to draw your clothes;
And not a carrier yet in town to send by.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I say once more go about it,
You're a wise man, you'd have me linger time,
Till I have worn these clothes out: will ye go?
Make ye ready wife. Exit. Jaques.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I am so, mighty Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nay for the country.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How? for the country?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes I am resolved to see my tenants in this bravery
Make them a sumptuous feast, with a slight show,
Of Dives, and Lazarus, and a squib or two,
And so return.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why sir? you are not mad?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How many Dukes have ye known mad? I pray speak.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You are the first sir, and I hope the last,
But you are stark horn mad.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Forbear good wife.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: As I have faith you're mad: your horns
Have been too heavy for you, and have broke
Your skull in pieces: if you be in earnest.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well you shall know my skull and wits are whole
Ere I have done, and yet I am in earnest.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why, do you think I'll go?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I know you shall.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I shall? by what authority shall I?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am your husband.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: True I confess it,
And by that name the world hath given you
A power to sway me; but sir you shall know
There is a greater bond that ties me here,
Allegiance to the King; has he not heaped
Those honours on you to no other end,
But to stay you here, and shall I have a hand
In the offending such a gracious prince?
Besides, our own undoings lies upon't,
Were there no other cause, I do not see,
Why you should go: if I should say you should not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yes faith.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now good wife make me understand that point.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why that you shall, did I not bring you hither?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: And were not all those honours wrought out of the fire by me?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: By you?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: By me; how strange you make it?
When you came first did you not walk the town,
In a long cloak half compass? an old hat,
Lined with velour, and on it for a band,
A skein of crimson cruel?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I confess it.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And took base courses?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Base?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Base by this light, extreme base, and scurvy, monstrous base.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What were these courses, wife?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why you shall know,
Did you not thus attired trot up and down,
Plotting for vild and lousy offices,
And agreed with the sergeant of the bears,
To buy his place? deny this if you can.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why it is true.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And was not that monstrous base?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be advised wife, a bear's a princely beast.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: A bear?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes wife, and one side venison.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You're more then one side fool, I'm sure of that

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But since you have vexed me wife, know you shall go
Nor you shall never have penny from me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Nay I have done, and though I know 'twill be
Your overthrow, I'll not forsake you now.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be ready then. Exit Duke.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What are you married Bewford?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.p: I as fast as words, and hearts, and hands and priest can make us.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O gentlemen, we are undone.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This gentleman the lord of lorne my husband,
Will be gone down to show his play fellows,
Where he is gay.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: What, down into the country?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yes faith, was ever fool but he so cross?
I would as fain be gracious to him,
As he could wish me, but he will not let me;
Speak faithfully, will he deserve my mercy?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: According to his merits he should wear,
A guarded coat, and a great wooden dagger.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: If there be any woman that doth know,
The duties 'twixt a husband and his wife,
Will speak but one word for him he shall scape;
Is not that reasonable? but there's none,
Be ready therefore, to pursue the plot
We had against a pinch, for he must stay.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Wait you here for him whilst I go
And make the King acquainted with your sport,
For fear he be incensed for our attempting;
Places of so great honour. Exit Long.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Go, be speedy.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Cozen, wife, Jaques, man.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come let me see how all things are disposed of.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: One cart will serve for all your furniture,
With room enough behind to ease the footman
A capcase for your linen, and your plate,
With a strange lock that opens with amen;
For my young lord because of easy portage,
A quiver of your graces lined with Cunny,
Made to be hanged about the nurse's neck,
Thus with a scarf or towel.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis well, but had you stayed another week,
I would have had you, furnished in such pomp,
As never Duke of Burgundy was furnished,
You should have had a sumpter though't had cost me
The laying on myself: where now you are fain,
To hire a ripper's mare, and buy new dossers,
But I have got them painted with your arms,
With a fair darnex carpet of my own
Laid cross for the more state.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques I thank you: your carpet shall be brushed
And sent you home; what, are you ready wife?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: An hour ago

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot choose but kiss thy royal lips,
Dear Duchess mine, thou art so good a woman.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: You'd say so if you knew all, goodman Duckling.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: This was the happiest fortune could befall me
Now in his absence will I follow close
Mine own preferment, and I hope e ere long,
To make my mean and humble name so strong,
As my great cousins, when the world shall know,
I bear too hot a spirit to live low
The next spring will I down my wife and household,
I'll have my ushers, and my four lackeys,
Six spare croches too: but mum, no more,
What I intend to do, I'll keep in store.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Mountye, mountye, Jaques, be our querry.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: To horse there gentlemen, and fall in couples.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come honoured Duchess. Enter Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Stand thou proud man.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thieves, Jaques, raise the people.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No, raise no people, 'tis the King's command,
Which bids thee once more stand thou haughty man,
Thou art a monster, for thou art ungrateful,
And like a fellow of a rebel nature,
Hast flung from his embraces: and for
His honours given thee, hast not returned
So much as thanks, and to oppose his will,
Resolved to leave the court, and set the realm
A fire, in discontent, and open action:
Therefore he bids thee stand thou proud man,
Whilst with the whisking of my sword about
I take thy honours off: this first sad whisk
Takes off thy dukedom, thou art but an Earl.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are mistaken, Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O would I were, this second whisk divides
Thy earldom from thee, thou art yet a baron.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No more whisks if you love me Longavile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Two whisks are past, and two are yet behind,
Yet all must come, but not to linger time.
With these two whisks I end, now mount marine,
For thou art now no more, so says the King,
And I have done his highness will with grief.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Disgraced from my honours?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: 'Tis too certain.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am no traitor sure that I know of;
Speak Jaques? hast thou ever heard me utter word
Tending to treason, or to bring in the enemy?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Alas sir I know nothing,
Why should your worship bring me in to hang me?
God's my judge gentlemen I never meddled
But with the brushing of his clothes, or fetching
In water in a morning for his hands.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Are these the honours of this place? Antony
Help me to take her gown off quickly
Or I'll so swinge ye for't â€”

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why husband? Sir?

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: I'll not lose a penny by this town.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Why what do you mean sir, have her to her lodging,
And there undress her, I will wait upon her.

sp.speaker: Cozener
sp.l: Indeed you shall not, your month is out I take it,
Get you out before me wife:
Cousin farewell, I told you long ago,
That pride begins with pleasure, ends with woe.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Go thy way sentences, 'twill be thy fortune,
To live and die a cuckold and churchwarden.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O my poor husband! what a heavy fortune
Is fallen upon him?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Methinks 'tis strange,
That heaven forewarning great men of their falls,
With such plain tokens, they should not avoid them?
For the last night betwixt eleven and twelve,
Two great and hideous blazing stars were seen
To fight a long hour by the clock, the one
Dressed like a Duke, the other like a King,
Till at the last the crowned star o'ercame.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why do ye stand so dead, monsieur Marine?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: So Caesar fell when in the Capitol
They gave his body two and thirty wounds.
Be warned all ye peers, and by my fall,
Hereafter learn to let your wives rule all.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Monsieur Marine, pray let me speak with you;
Sir I must wave you to conceal this party,
It stands upon my utter overthrow;
Seem not discontented, nor do not stir a foot,
For if you do, you and your hope â€”
I swear you are a lost man if you stir.
And have an eye to Bewford, he'll tempt you.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Come, come, for shame go down;
Were I marine, by heaven I would go down:
And being there, I would rattle him such an answer
Should make him smoke.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Good monsieur Bewford peace
Leave these rebellious words,
Or by the honours which I once enjoyed,
And yet may swear by,
I'll tell the King of your proceedings;
I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You talked of going down when 'twas not fit,
But now let's see your spirit,
A thousand and a thousand will expect it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why wife, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No nor drunk, but I'd have you know your own strength

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You talk like a most foolish woman wife;
I tell you I will stay, yet I have a
Cratchet troubles me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: More crotchets yet?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Follow me Jaq. I must have thy counsel,
I will return again, stay you there wife.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I fear this loss of honour will give him some few stools.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, no, he is resolved, he will not
Stir a foot I'll lay my life.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: I but he's discontented, how shall we resolve that
And make him stay with comfort?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Faith Bewford we must even let nature work,
For he's the sweetest tempered man for that
As one can wish, for let men but go about to fool him,
And he'll have his finger as deep in 't as the best;
But see where he comes frowning, bless us all!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Off with your hats, for here doth come
The high and mighty Duke of Burgundy.
Whatever you may think, I have thought
And thought, and thought upon't, and I find it plain,
The King cannot take back what he has given,
Unless I forfeit it by course of law.
Not all the water in the river seen,
Can wash the blood out of these princely veins.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: God a mercy husband, thou art the best
To work out a thing at a pinch, in France.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I will ascend my state again,
Duchess take your place,
And let our champion enter.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Has he his champion? that's excellent.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And let loud music sound before his entrance.
Sound trumpet.

div.stage: Enter Jaques in armour, one carrying a scuchion before him, and a two-handed sword.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: How well our champion doth demean himself,
As if he had been made for such an action?
Methinks his sturdy truncheon he doth wield,
Like Mars approaching to a bloody field.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I think there's no man so desperate
To dare encounter with our champion,
But trust me, Jaques, thou hast pleased us well;
Once more our warlike music, then proceed. En: Shat.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: What wondrous age is this? what close proceedings?
I hear the clang of trumpets in this house,
To what intent do not our statesmen search?
O no, they look not into simple truth;
For I am true, and they regard not me,
A man in armour too: God save the King
The world will end, there's naught but treachery.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I Ja. servant to the high and mighty Godfrey Duke of Burgundy, do come hither to prove by natural strength and activity of my body, without the help of sorcery, enchantment, or negromancy, that the said Godfrey late of mount Marine, and now of Burgundy, hath perfect right thereto, notwithstanding the Kings command to the contrary, and no other person whatsoever: and in token that I will be ready to make good the same: I throw down my gage, whichis my honour, pronounced the 37. of Feb. stilo novo, God save the D.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Of all the plots the King hath laid for me
This was the shrewdest, 'tis my life they seek,
And they shall have it: if I should refuse
To accept the challenge in the King's behalf,
They have some cause to take away my life,
And if I do accept it, who can tell,
But I may fall by doubtful chance of war?
'Twas shrewd, but I must take the least of evils,
I take thy gauntlet up thou treacherous man,
That stands in armed coat against the King,
Whom God preserve, and with my single sword
Will justify whatever he commands;
I'll watch him for catching of my words.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques go on, defend our princely title.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Why shrinkest thou back? thou hast an evil cause;
Come forward man, I have a rock about me,
I fight for my true liege.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Go forward Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace to pardon me,
I will not fight with him, with any else
I'll show my resolution speedily.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Come do thy worst, for the King shall see
All is not true that is reported of me.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I may not fight with him by law of arms.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What? shall my title fall? wilt thou not fight?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Never with him that once hath saved my life.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Darest thou not fight? behold then I do go
Strong with the zeal I bear my sovereign,
And seize upon that haughty man himself.
Descend the steps that (Thou hast thus usurped
Against the King and state) down to the ground,
And if thou do utter but a syllable
To cross the King's intent, thou art but dead;
There, lie upon the earth and pine and die.
Did ever any man wade through such storms,
To save his life, as poor Shattillion?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I fear this challenge hath spoiled all.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Never fear it, he'll work it out again servant.
See where shattillions love, poor lady, comes. En: love.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Lie still sir if you love your life, I'll whistle when he's gone,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: O gentlemen, I charge you by the love
Which you bear to women, take some pity
On this distressed man, help to restore
That precious jewel to him he hath lost.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Lady whatever power doth lie in us
By art or prayer, or danger, we are yours,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: A strange conceit hath wrought this malady,
Conceits again must bring him to himself,
My strict denial to his will wrought this?
And if you could but draw his wilder thoughts
To know me, he would sure recover sense.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: That charge I'll undertake.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Look Jaques, look, for god's sake let me rise,
This greatness is a jade, I cannot sit it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: His sword is up, and yet he watcheth you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I'll down again, pray for thy master, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Now the King may see all the suggestions are not true,
He hath received against my loyalty;
When all men else refuse, I fight his battles,
And thrust my body into danger's mouth;
I am become his champion, and this sword
Has taught his enemies to know themselves;
Oh that he would no more be jealous of me!

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Monsieur Shattillion, the King assigns you,
That for this valiant loyal act of yours,
He hath forgotten all jealousies and fears,
And never more will tempt you into danger.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: But how shall I believe this? what new token
Of reconcilement will he show me?
Let him release my poor love from her torment,
From her hard fare and strict imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: He hath done this to win your after-love,
And see your lady sent you from the King
By these two gentlemen: be thankful for her.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: She lives, she lives, I know her by the power
Shoots from her eyes.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Rise dear Shattillion.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I know my duty,
Next unto my King, I am to kneel to you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll have you rise, fetch me a chair, sit down shalt.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: I am commanded, and faith tell me mistress,
What usage have you had? pray be plain?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: O my most loved Shattillion, pain enough,
But now I am free, thanks to my god and King.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: His eyes grow very heavy, not a word,
That his weak senses may come sweetly home.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: The King is honourable.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: When do you whistle Jaques?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: By and by.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Come hither monsieur, canst thou laugh a little?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: So thou shalt then. Bewford how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why well.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'm glad on't, and how does thy wife?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Why you may see her sir, she stands behind you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: By the mass she's there indeed, but where's her belly?

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Belly?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Her great belly man: what hast thou sent thee?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: A boy I'll lay my life, it tumbled so.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Caught by this light.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I'll be a gossip Bewford.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I have an odd apostle spoon.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: S'foot catched.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why what's the matter gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: He's married to your woman.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And I not know it?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Twas a venial sin.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Gall, gall, gall.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Forgive her Monsieur Bewford, 'twas her love.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: You may rise if you please, I must endure it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: See how my great lord lies upon the ground
And dare not stir yet?
Jaques, whistles?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Jaques, Jaq. is the King's champion gone yet,

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: No, but he's asleep.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is he asleep art sure?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I am sure he is, I hear him snore.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then by your favours gentlemen I rise,
And know I am a Duke still.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And I am his champion.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Hold thee there, and all France cannot mend thee.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I am a prince as great within my thoughts
As when the whole state did adorn my person;
What trial can be made to try a prince?
I will oppose this noble corpse of mine
To any danger that may end the doubt.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Great Duke and husband there is but one way
To satisfy the world of our true right,
And it is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What may it be?
Were it to bring the great Turk bound in chains
Through France in triumph: or to couple up
The sophy, and great Prester John together,
I would attempt it Duchess, tell the course.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: There is a strong opinion through the world,
And no doubt grounded on experience
That lions will not touch a lawful prince,
If you be confident then of your right,
Amongst the lions bear your naked body,
And if you come off clear and never winch,
The world will say you are a perfect prince.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I thank you Duchess for your kind advice,
But now we do not affect those ravenous beasts.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: A lion is a beast to try a King;
But for the trial of such a state like this
Pliny reports a mastive dog will serve.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We will not deal with dogs at all: but men.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You shall not need to deal with them at all,
Hark you sir, the King doth know you are a Duke:

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No, does he?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes, and is content you shall be, but with this caution,
That none know it but yourself:
For if ye do, he'll take it away by act of parliament.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Here's my hand, and whilst I live or breath,
No living wight shall know I am a Duke.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Mark me directly sir, your wife may know it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: May not Jaques?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes, he may.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: May not my country cousin?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: By no means sir, if you love your life and state.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well then, know all I am no Duke.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: No I'll swear it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: See he wakes.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Where am I, or where have I been all this while?
Sleep hath not sat so sound upon mine eyes
But I remember well that face;
Oh thou too cruel, leave at length to scorn
Him that but looking on thy beauty dies,
Either receive me, or put out my eyes.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: Dearest Shattillion see upon my knees,
I offer up my love, forget my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Art thou mine own?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: By heaven I am.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Then all the world is mine.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.l: I have stranger things to tell thee, my dearest love.

sp.speaker: Shat.
sp.l: Tell nothing but that thou art mine own:
I do not care to know where I have been,
Or how I have lived, or any thing,
But that thou art my own.

sp.speaker: Bew.
sp.l: Well wife, though 'twere a trick that made us wed,
We'll make ourselves merry soon in bed.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Know all I am no Duke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What say?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Jaques?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I am a Duke.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Are ye?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes faith, yes faith.
But it must only run amongst ourselves,
And Jaques thou shalt be my secretary still.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Kind gentlemen, lead in Shattillion,
For he must needs be weak and sickly yet.
Now all my labours have a perfect end as I could wish,
Let all young sprightly wives that have
Dull foolish coxcombs to their husbands,
Learn by me their duties, what to do,
Which is to make 'em fools, and please 'em too.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: Wit is become an antic: and puts on
To court the time's applause, as the times dare,
Change several fashions, nothing is thought rare
Which is not new and followed, yet we know,
That what was worn some twenty year ago,
Comes into grace again, and we pursue
That custom, by presenting to your view
A play in fashion then, not doubting now
But 'twill appear the same, if you allow
Worth to their noble memory, whose name,
Beyond all power of death live in their fame.

div.head: The epilogue.
div.l: The monuments of virtue and desert,
Appear more goodly when the gloss of art
Is eaten off by time, then when at first
They were set up, not censured at the worst.
We have done our best for your contents to fit
With new pains this old monument of wit.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
